posts.name: Soc Virnyl S. Estela
posts.cooked:
Everyone already knows about Flatpak if you are a Linux user. For more details, anyone can just read it from their homepage - https://flatpak.org/.

Hello everyone, I am a new user of Signal. And I just recently installed Signal from the unofficial flatpak. I believe that if someone from Signal is willing to maintain the Flatpak of Signal - GitHub - flathub/org.signal.Signal - I think it will increase the level of trust when users install Signal through Flatpak. As flatpak is increasing in popularity because of the changing direction towards the distribution of software in Linux, I think it’s fine for Signal to officially take ownership of the unofficial flatpak.

What are the benefits of using flatpak?

Through flatpak, you build your software, you distribute it to almost any Linux distribution, reducing the burden of maintaining the package. OBS Studio and Bottles use this approach so they won’t have to deal with issues with dependencies and increases the likelihood that bugs are actually from the software and not the distribution, not the dependencies, not version conflicts, not whatsoever.

Flatpak claims to be secure or at least from what I understand, adds an additional layer of security through sandbox which can be controlled by the user through permissions. I am no security expert so I will leave that to them (or to you).

And lastly, build it once, run it everywhere (just on Linux distributions though). This means that Signal installed through flatpak will be the same version in Debian, openSUSE, and Fedora.

However, the Signal Flatpak is unofficial so taking ownership on that one may help users (or the maintainers of Signal) in the long-term.

posts.cooked: Signal is already a big electron blob. Installed size of signal-desktop from official repository is 422,9 MB. Flatpak’s size is 434,8 MB. It requires Freedesktop Platform runtime which is 575 MB, so together it’s about 1 GB, but runtime is shared between other flatpaks. I’m in favor of taking the ownership. I’ve been using Signal from flatpak on Fedora for over a year without problems. If not for flatpak, I probably wouldn’t be even able to use Signal on desktop without building from source or inconvenient manual converting of official deb or something like that. Flatpak permission system is an additional plus given how focused on security Signal team is.

Great suggestion.

Flatpaks are like portable containers. build once, install pretty much any linux distro without worrying about dependencies, as it is all self contained sandboxed apps. Seems like the broader linux community is in favour of flatpaks, esp the openSUSE community with immutable distros ramping up in this space.

posts.name: Jessica
posts.cooked:
I recently worked on restarting the beta builds for the Flatpak, and agree it would be nice to have it officially supported for other platforms.

Right now, the Flatpak basically unpacks the .deb and manually installs the components. It’s not ideal, but it minimizes the number of compatibility issues (with the exception of native Wayland).

The devs may prefer to build from source, which would be a bit more effort to support and might explain why they haven’t planned to offer it yet.

posts.cooked: The problem is that when they officially make Signal available for other platforms, they then have to support those platforms. That is why they only build for Debian-based systems right now; the team is too small to provide support for a bunch of different distros with infinite configurations. I don’t know if the nature of flatpak alleviates any of that, but it definitely doesn’t eliminate it entirely. So it seems unlikely to happen for now.

posts.name: Soc Virnyl S. Estela
posts.cooked:
I do think the flatpak approach will alleviate the burden if and only if the devs plan to support other platforms. The idea is if we support flatpak as a distribution format, they can still choose the dependencies they want to use and make sure these dependencies are contained within the flatpak and it will not depend on the infinite configurations you mentioned. This means that even if I use Signal from let’s say, openSUSE Tumbleweed, Signal flatpak’s dependencies matches those as if it was in a Debian-based system, if so desired.

There is also a post that supporting this distribution model can help packagers and devs lessen the burden of maintaining software across different linux distributions.

EDIT: but again, the decision is up to the developers, not me. It does not mean I will antagonize them for not officially taking ownership or support flatpak. Maintaining an open source project takes time and I understand that. I do hope they will adopt this model because I really do believe it lessens their burden if they so want to distribute Signal Desktop officially for other Linux distributions

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

The problem is that when they officially make Signal available for other platforms, they then have to support those platforms.

Not really. One of the benefits of Flatpak is that you really only have to support one package - the flatpak. Since it comes with all the dependencies, the distro running in the background doesn’t matter, the problem is either with the package, with flatpak as a whole (which means it isn’t Signal’s problem), or as we call it in the tech space, “between laptop and chair”.

posts.name: Soc Virnyl S. Estela
posts.cooked: Thanks for making it clear. That’s what I mean that it will lessen the burden of the devs and packagers.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Yes! That’s why so many people call it “the future of packaging”.
Yes, it has disadvantages, but those are vastly outweighed by the time it saves developers, at least in my opinion.

posts.name: Soc Virnyl S. Estela
posts.cooked: My wish now is if the devs see this post and reconsider. <3

Talya (she/her):

the distro running in the background doesn’t matter

That’s not entirely true; you can still have distro-specific issues, or problems with things being different due to the window manager used, etc. It makes it so that packaging your app is straightforward, but that is only part of the picture.

It’s the same as how using Electron makes it easier to be cross-platform, but there are still plenty of issues because of differences in OS.

Here is a conversation I have with some of the OBS people. It’s in Discord though so I will copy the text here, sorry for the long text!:

[Start of Conversation]

uncomfyhalomacro: Hello. Are the devs here? I have a question about why OBS switched to flatpak? And what benefits it brings? Actually I know the advantages but needs some clarification on your side. Does OBS as a flatpak avoid distro-specific issues entirely or partially? And how does it alleviate this if it’s true (or partially true) that it does?

Matt: “Switched” is a strong term, officially we exclusively supported Ubuntu only before Flatpak. Flatpak allows us to provide official builds that should work on all distros. Building many distro-specific versions of OBS is more work than our very small team can handle.

uncomfy: It’s related for my info gathering to encourage SignalApp to take ownership of their unofficial Flatpak. Link to my query to them: Taking ownership of Signal Flatpak?

uncomfy:

“Switched” is a strong term, officially we exclusively supported Ubuntu only before Flatpak. Flatpak allows us to provide official builds that should work on all distros. Building many distro-specific versions of OBS is more work than our very small team can handle.

sorry my bad. thanks for correcting. So flatpak helps alleviate your distributing of OBS to various distributions then?

EDIT: oh you already answered the question hmm

Matt: The Flatpak very much allow us to provide a fully-functioning baseline that works on all distros, and to ensure all features are enabled (eg. browser source and VST2 support). There are still some community-run distro-specific builds due to some Flatpak limitations that those users look to avoid, but usually if a user has issues with those builds we ask if they have tested the Flatpak to cut out any possibility of it being a build issue anyway.
Honestly, overall, Flatpak has been quite nice to work with both on the technical side and the community side.

Kurufu: “Does OBS as a flatpak avoid distro-specific issues entirely or partially?”, basically no is the short answer. But of the various competing “futures of packaging” flatpak has maintainers dealing with most of the support for these distro-specific bits instead of us dealing with it. And at least when I reported issues they were well received and fixed.

Matt: I’d say it avoids some and introduces new issues. But that’s going to be any system that tries to do similar things.

Kurufu: True, there is no way around these issues regardless of the tool.

uncomfy:

True, there is no way around these issues regardless of the tool.

ah i guess i was wrong then. i stand corrected.

feaneron: In addition to that, we need to ship patched dependencies, like CEF and FFmpeg (is it still the case though?), and that’s difficult with traditional packaging systems

Matt: Especially as a lot of distros tend to hold either outdated packages or don’t provide certain packages due to licensing

uncomfy:

Especially as a lot of distros tend to hold either outdated packages or don’t provide certain packages due to licensing

it’s one reason I use flatpak over e.g. zypper because openSUSE does not provide the necessary codecs due to licensing

uncomfy:

In addition to that, we need to ship patched dependencies, like CEF and FFmpeg (is it still the case though?), and that’s difficult with traditional packaging systems

so you mean the advantages far outweigh the disadvantages?
or is it just a trade off between those things if a user wants to use flatpak and/or traditional package manager their system provides

feaneron: I can’t really speak on behalf of the entire community, but in my opinion, yes, I think it’s been beneficial for the project
OBS Studio is a large, complex app that is pushing the ecossystem into a better place
There are examples of new features in Flathub, and the desktop portals that were direct contributions from people involved with OBS, or at least informed by what we do here
We were the first app to integrate a publishing pipeline from our GitHub CI into Flathub directly

uncomfy:

We were the first app to integrate a publishing pipeline from our GitHub CI into Flathub directly

welp that trivia i didnt know

feaneron: Yeah. Releases are fully automated these days; we publish a new version of OBS, and Flathub magically deploys the update to dozens of thousands of people, without any manual intervention. It’s quite nice

uncomfy: Hmm I wonder if my suggestion could really make Signal take ownership of the unofficial flatpak given this info from why OBS has flatpak. but again, I am just an ignorant user. maybe there are some variables and factors for why they didn’t.

Anyway thanks again! I understand somewhat your reasons for distributing OBS as a flatpak.

Matt: Our main reason was “we want more users to have access to OBS with as many features functional as possible, while keeping Linux maintenance about the same as before (or slightly higher)”

uncomfy: would it be okay if I share this conversation to the post I mentioned?

Matt: Of course.

[End of Conversation]

Very well put!

Flatpak uses bubblewrap as a sandboxing tool, which runs without needing root. Bubblewrap confines every app to its own space, by default that is a a container just like on android, with accessible data purely being in ~/.var/app/org.signal.Signal.

The unofficial Flatpak is great already, Signal supports pipewire and the filepicker portal already, which are 2 things needed for secure apps on Linux.

So the only problems users reported is the lack of drag&drop (missing Flatpak portal) and maybe more that I am not aware of. The app is really well packaged without any issues.

I guess they use zypak, as Signal uses Electron which uses Chromium, which wants to create user namespaces for the processes. This should be uncritical as Signal is a single process afaik.

Flatpak is a blessing for the Linux Desktop and far preferred over Snap or the horrible Appimages, as it combines a universal format with security, shared libraries, deduplication of dependencies, appstream metadata and a nice UI.
No, Flatpak uses runtimes and deduplicates between them.
